guide.introduction: I certainly appreciate the craftsmanship of stained glass, but I’ve come up with something that gives a similar effect without the prerequisite labor. Though it may not look exactly like stained glass, it’s a quick and easy rendition that easily jazzes up my windows.
guide.introduction_rendered:
I certainly appreciate the craftsmanship of stained glass, but I’ve come up with something that gives a similar effect without the prerequisite labor. Though it may not look exactly like stained glass, it’s a quick and easy rendition that easily jazzes up my windows.

Relevant parts
  • Plastic folders
  • Silver glue sticks
  • Tape
  • Paper
Tools
  • Hot glue gun
  • Marker
  • Scissors

parts.notes: Transparent plastic folders in different colors. Most office supply or dollar stores carry them.
Large sheet of paper on which to draw your design.

lines.text: Draw your design on a large piece of paper with a thick marker. This will allow you to see it under the plastic pieces.
lines.text_raw: Draw your design on a large piece of paper with a thick marker. This will allow you to see it under the plastic pieces.

lines.text: Decide which colors go where, then lay your plastic folders over your drawing and start tracing the shapes. Use 2 colors together to create different colors, such as blue and red to make purple, just as with paint.
lines.text_raw: Decide which colors go where, then lay your plastic folders over your drawing and start tracing the shapes. Use 2 colors together to create different colors, such as blue and red to make purple, just as with paint.

lines.text: Cut out your shapes and place them on your drawing.
lines.text_raw: Cut out your shapes and place them on your drawing.

lines.text: Once all the pieces are cut out and placed on the design, tape them together with very small pieces of tape. Fold over the end of the tape so it’s easy to remove while you work.
lines.text_raw: Once all the pieces are cut out and placed on the design, tape them together with very small pieces of tape. Fold over the end of the tape so it’s easy to remove while you work.

lines.text: Using your hot glue gun, glue your pieces together along the seams where they meet. Wipe off the tip of the glue gun regularly with an old rag to keep your beads of glue neat.
lines.text_raw: Using your hot glue gun, glue your pieces together along the seams where they meet. Wipe off the tip of the glue gun regularly with an old rag to keep your beads of glue neat.

lines.text: Glue all around the edges of your stained glass piece to give it a finished edge.
lines.text_raw: Glue all around the edges of your stained glass piece to give it a finished edge.

lines.text: Using small pieces of tape, place the faux stained glass on your window to position it where you want it.
lines.text_raw: Using small pieces of tape, place the faux stained glass on your window to position it where you want it.

lines.text: Using tiny beads of clear hot glue, adhere the stained glass piece to your window every 5" or so. You can easily remove it when it’s time for a change.
lines.text_raw: Using tiny beads of clear hot glue, adhere the stained glass piece to your window every 5" or so. You can easily remove it when it’s time for a change.

guide.summary: Craft a quick and easy window cover.
